gurmukhi: C`qR kitE niRp ko jb hI qb hI mn BUpq kop BXo hY ]sXwm kI Er kudiRSit icqY kir augR srwsn hwQ lXo hY ]
transliteration: Chhattra Katio Nrip Ko Jab Hitab Himan Bhoopat Kop Bhayo Hai|| Syaam Kior Kudrishttee Chitai Kar(i) Ougra Saraasan Haath Layo Hai||
translation: With the chopping down of the canopy, the king got highly infuriated; and he, looking towards Krishna with evil glance, took his dreadful bow in his hand;

gurmukhi: jor so KYNcn lwgXo qhw nih AYc skY kr kMp BXo hY ]lY Dnu bwn murwr qbY iqh cwNp ctwk dY kwit dXo hY ]1856]
transliteration: Jor So Khainchanndlaagyo Tahaa Nah(i) Aich Sakai Kar Kanp Bhayo Hai|| Lai Dhan(u) Baan Muraar Tabai Tih Chaanp Chataak Dai Kaattee Dayo Hai||1856||
translation: He began to pull the bow with force, but his hand trembled and the bow could not be pulled; at the same time, Krishna with his bow and arrows intercepted with jerk the bow of Jarasandh.1856.

gurmukhi: biRjrwj srwsn kwt dXo qb BUpq kopu kIXo mn mY ]krvwr sMBwr mhw bl Dwr hkwr prXo irp ky gn mY ]
transliteration: Brijraaj Saraasan Kaat Dayo Tab Bhoopat Kop(u) Keeyo Man Mai|| Karvaar Sanbhaar Mahaa Bal Dhaar Hakaar Daryo Rip Ke Gad Mai||
translation: When Krishna intercepted the bow or Jarasandh, he, getting, enraged and challenging, took his sword in his hand and fell upon the enemy’s army;

gurmukhi: qhw Fwl so Fwl kiRpwn kiRpwn so XoN Atky Ktky rn mY ]mno jÍwl dvwnl kI lptY ctkY ptkY qiRn ijau bn mY ]1857]
transliteration: Tahaa Dhaal So Dhaal Kridaan Kridaan So Yon Atke Khatke Ran Mai|| Mano Jvaal Dvaanal Kilaptai Chatkai Patkai Trin Jio Ban Mai||1857||
translation: The shield collided with the shield and the sword with the sword in such a way as if straw were producing a cracking sound on burning, having been set on fire in the forest.1857.

gurmukhi: GUmq Gwiel huie iek bIr iPrY sRaun Bry BBkwqy ]eyk kbMD iPrY ibn sIs lKY iqn kwier hY ibllwqy ]
transliteration: Ghoomat Fhaail Hue Ik Beer Phirai Ik Sraoun Bhare Bhabhkaate|| Ek Kabandh Phirai Bin Sees Lakhai Tin Kaair Hai Bil-laate||
translation: Someone, getting wounded, was roaming, thworing away blood and someone was roaming without head, becoming only a headless trunk; seeing which the cowards are getting frightened;

gurmukhi: qXwg cly iek Awhv ko iek folq ju`Dh ky rMg rwqy ]eyk pry Bt pRwn ibnw mno sovq hY mdrw md mwqy ]1858]
transliteration: Tyaag Chale Ik Aahav Ko Ik Dolat Juddhah Ke Ran Raate|| Ek Dare Bhat Praan Binaa Mano Sovat Hai Madraa Mad Maate||1858||
translation: Some of the warriors, leaving the war-fray are running away; some of them are absorbed in war, getting intoxicated; some warriors are lying lifeless like the ones highly intoxicated after drinking wine.1858.

gurmukhi: jwdv jy Aiq kRop BrY gih AwXuD isMD jrw pih Dwvq ]Aaur ijqy isrdwr blI krvwr sMBwr hkwr bulwvq ]
transliteration: Jaadav Je At(i) Krodh Bdarai Gadh Aayudh Sindh Jaraa Pah(i) Dhaavat|| Aur Jite Sirdaar Balikarvaar Sanbhaar Hakaar Bulaavat||
translation: In extreme fury, the Yadavas, holding their weapons, have fallen on Jarasandh; the mighty warriors, taking up their swords are challenging all;

gurmukhi: BUpq pwn lY bwn kmwn gumwn BrXo irp Er clwvq ]eyk hI bwn ky swQ kIey ibn mwQ sunwQ AnwQ huie Awvq ]1859]
transliteration: Bhoopat Paan Lai Baan Kamaan Goumaan Bdaryo Rip Or Chadaavat|| Ek Hibaan Ke Saath Keee Bin Maath Sounaath Anaath Hue Aavat||1859||
translation: The king Jarasandh, taking his bow in his hand, is proudly discharging his arrows towards the enemies and even with a single arrow, he is routing many, making them headless.1859.

gurmukhi: eykn kI Buj kwit deI Aru eykn ky isr kwit igrwey ]jwdv eyk kIey ibrQI puin sRI jdubIr ko qIr lgwey ]
transliteration: Ekan Kibhuj Kaattee Daiar(u) Ekan Ke Sir Kaattee Giraae|| Jaadav Ek Keee Birthipoun(i) Srijadoubeer Ko Teer Lagade||
translation: He cut down the arm of someone and caused the head of someone fall down after cutting it; some Yadava was deprived of his chariot; then he shot an arrow towards Krishna;

gurmukhi: Aaur hny gjrwj Gny br bwj bny hin BUim igrwey ]jogin BUq ipswc siRgwlin sRaunq swgr mwJ AnHwey ]1860]
transliteration: Aur Hane Gadraaj Ghane Bar Baaj Hane Han(i) Bhoom(i) Giraae|| Jogad(i) Bhoot Pisaach Srigadlan(i) Sraounat Saagad Maajh Anhaae||1860||
translation: He got many horses and elephants killed and fell on the ground; and the Yoginis, ghosts, fiends, jackals etc., began to bathe in the sea of blood in the battlefield.1860.
